description: From Latin mīmicus, from Ancient Greek μῑμικός (mīmikós, “belonging to mimes”), from μῖμος (mîmos, “imitator, actor”); see mime.

examples: And there, with fingers interwoven, both handsPressed closely palm to palm and to his mouthUplifted, he, as through an instrument,Blew mimic hootings to the silent owls,That they might answer him.

entries.meaning: (mineralogy) Imitative; characterized by resemblance to other forms; applied to crystals which by twinning resemble simple forms of a higher grade of symmetry.

definitionGroups.group: A person who practices mimicry; especially:

entries.meaning: An entity that mimics another entity, such as a disease that resembles another disease in its signs and symptoms; see the great imitator.

verbs.description: mimic (third-person singular simple present mimics, present participle mimicking, simple past and past participle mimicked)

entries.meaning: To imitate, especially in order to ridicule.
(biology) To take on the appearance of another, for protection or camouflage.
